comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: "The paddle punt Warrane was built in 1883 and had an open wheelhouse. She was rated as being able to carry fourteen vehicles and up to 109 passengers." (ref. PIctorial History of Ferries, Graeme Andrews, Reed 1982). Coincidentally Harold Cazneaux photographed the same (altered) ferry ca. 1920 - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an2345949 - used as an illustration in the above book. Another later picture and more information: www.ferriesofsydney.com/warrane.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The horse ferry used to operate between Milsons Point and the west side of Fort Macquarie (Bennelong Point), from where this photo was taken. See this 1895 map of Sydney - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The Warrane features in this 1898 T&CJ article 'North Shore Horse-Ferry Improvements' - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71319992

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Here is a test for you.  Is this photo the interior of the Dawes Point Baths (see note) or somewhere else;  if so where?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
'The Old Horse Ferry'

The old horse ferry is a democratic boat,
For she mixes up the classes more than any craft afloat;
And the cart of Bill the Bottle-o, and the sulky of his boss,
Might stand each side the motor car of Mrs Buster-Cross.

Oh, the old horse ferry is a parliament of man,
Where everything is settled, or left just where it began;
But the old horse ferry is a very peaceful scow,
For you seldom hear a swear-word, and you never hear a row.

It's a rest for weary horses from the hot hard roads and steep;
And the young ones shake their winkers, and old 'Geddup' goes to sleep;
Just to wake up short and sudden when she bumps the landing stage,
Like a slamming door might wake you when you nod in your old age.

The old horse ferry is a private way between,
For the down-and-out and shabby who care not to be seen.
And the man who shakes and suffers from the reckless night before,
And shuns the eyes of passengers who know him on the Shore.

He'll mostly find his dodging and repentance is in vain - 
He'll get outside a drink or two, and do the same again;
But, same again, or not again, you'll have to go to town,
And the old horse ferry will never turn you down.

Henry Lawson (1914)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] It seems the old workhorse 'Warrane' was an object of affection. Did a bit of Troving - there's a half-scale "builders model" at the Powerhouse Museum dated 1882 - from.ph/211568

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=893319# see pic 15 (on page 2) in this SLNSW album...Henry Lawson with some of the horse ferry deckhands...taken shortly before he died. Amazin'!
